Everywhere I go, from Seattle to Spokane, I hear about this crisis, so I know firsthand that Washington state families are counting on us to deliver on child care.

I'm going to keep fighting each and every day to get my legislation passed and finally fix this.

My legislation dramatically expands pre-k, makes sure child care workers are paid a living wage, and helps families find child care near them.

Simply put, my Child Care for Working Families Act will transform child care in America and finally end this crisis.

My bill tackles this crisis via every angle possible to:

✅ lower families' child care costs
✅ expand families’ options
✅ support child care providers & workers

The typical family will pay no more than $10 a day for child care—& many will paying nothing at all.

This is holding our economy back. The child care crisis is costing us $122 BILLION in economic losses every single year.

We need bold action to address this—and my legislation delivers just that.

All the while, child care providers are struggling to stay afloat, child care workers are making poverty wages, and waitlists are getting longer and longer—all of which is leaving families with fewer options.

None of this is sustainable.

First, let's talk about the status of child care in our country right now. Simply put, it's a crisis.

Over the last 3 decades, the cost of child care has increased by 220%, forcing families to make impossible choices about going to work or caring for their child.

ICYMI: this week I reintroduced my Child Care for Working Families Act—my plan for tackling our nation's child care crisis head-on.
